title: Z-probe bracket for capacitive sensor on Mendel90

description.text:
I made a remix of DanielBulls excellent design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:599262 to fit a capacitive sensor instead of a inductive sensor.
The capacitive sensor has a bigger diameter but has the advantage over inductive sensors that it doesn't need a metal surface to be triggered. It works with any hard surface like glass, plastic, wood etc..
I use the LJC18A3-H-Z/BX capacitive sensor with this bracket.

comments.text:
Oooo I didn't know those capacitive sensors worked on glass, thats useful!
How are you getting on with it?
Repeatable results?

comments.text:
Sorry for the late reply.
I have not been able to test the sensor yet, because I been struggling with the upload of new Marlin firmware to the Melzi. I finally sorted it out but now the Auto leveling section of the Marlin code is giving me a headache!
I´m trying to get the grid mode to work but I get the following error when compiling: "
The Y axis probing range is not enough to fit all the points defined in AUTO_BED_LEVELING_GRID_POINTS"
or
"The X axis probing range is not enough to fit all the points defined in AUTO_BED_LEVELING_GRID_POINTS"
or both...
comments.author: DanielBull

comments.text: I gave up on grid levelling in Marlin, I had exactly the same problem even when I went to 0-200 x 0-200. I commented out the section of code that made the error message and it then compiled but I never got good results from it. To this day I still don't understand why that error occurs, it didn't seem logical to me that the offset should affect how many grid points you can do.

remixed_from.author: ScanSource3D
remixed_from.title: iPhone 6 Plus Dock w/ Integrated Watch Charging Station

description.text:
I cut the watch stand from the one made by @ScanSource3D. The problem is that I didn't like the print when I would lay it flat on the side and the extrusion lines wouldn't be in the best layout for support and structure. So re-did everything going off of the measurements from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:864011

With having 3 parts to print you can lay them flat to get a good structure for them.

I didn't sink the charger all the way down in the part because I wanted a little space between the top of the charger and the model. You can see in one of the pictures above.

Why so many parts?
I made this so that you can have an Apple Watch stand that is left or right oriented. It is up to you. If you are really cool and have two apple watches, you could connect both sides and have a sweet little watch stand.

This is probably the only Double Apple Watch stand out there (probably not). If you do the Twin watch stand, you most likely will have to do it in ABS and then use Acetone to weld both sides on. You will want to print the "no holes" .STL files for that.

I have supplied files with holes that take a 20mm M3 screw and washer. You may want to tap (M3 x .05 tap) out the holes because I made them tight. I have also supplied files without holes if you want to weld them up with Super Glue or Acetone.

If you want a LEFT facing stand (support on right) with holes for screws

  • download the 3 files with the word "left" in the name

If you want a RIGHT facing stand (support on the left) with holes for screws

  • download the 3 files with the word "right" in the name

If you want to glue/weld (no screws)

  • download the 3 files with the words "no holes" depending on which side you want. The SIDE model will be the same for either.

If you want the TWIN (watches on both sides)

  • download all the files with the words (no holes) in the name

Printer:

Micro M3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

15%

Notes:

You will need support only on the SIDE file. This is for the cut out that the charger cable runs down.
Other than that, no support is needed as long as you put the bottoms for the TOP and BASE flat on the bed. For the side, just put the large flat side on the bed.

Designed in OnShape

You can edit this model by using OnShape and going here https://cad.onshape.com/documents/f9fe7aa2b1afa30bed06a29c/w/584b59dd8855e78ed5ab2fe1/e/f9fe1e37289604b997453b51

This is a 3mm acrylic laser cut enclosure for the Lulzbot Taz6 enclosure. It uses the corner brackets to hold it in place and encloses the whole printer. If you don't have access to a laser cutter you can purchase a kit that includes everything except the 3d printed parts at https://printedsolid.com/products/lulzbot-taz-6-safety-enclosure-kit

This design is based on lots of research and time and tested by multiple companies and users and I am very proud to bring it to the public.

comments.text: Regarding the ventilation question, I can't think of any reason that it would be a problem to not have the cutouts. I suppose at some point extra heat in the enclosure could be problematic, but I would be extremely surprised if you reached that point. These panels do not produce a tight fit - there are several other air gaps in the design, including a big slot in the top panel for the filament.

comments.text: I just modified a couple of the panels. On Panel F I deleted the fan slots and fan mounting holes, on Panel Q, i removed the cutouts for the side mounted filament spool parts. You will have to remove those parts in order to fit the panel on your TAZ 6, obviously.

title: BSides Boise 2016 BYOB
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here it is! The BSides Boise 2016 BYOB - not beer, badge.
http://www.bsidesboise.org/

In what is surely a conference first we are letting the makers in our community make their very own badge for the BSides Boise 2016 conference. We'll still ask for a donation at the door on the day of the conference and we are at this moment printing a vast array of unique BSides Boise 2016 badges in all sorts of colors for those non-makers out there who will be attending the conference and playing this years combined badge challenge / CTF.

You can print this one without modification or choose to modify it to your liking. Want your name on it? Cool. Want to add gears? Cool. Want to make it whatever size you want? I'd recommend you do. The only thing we ask is that you keep the BSides Boise logo, year, and that it maintains an emoticon theme.

If you want to publish a remix on Thingiverse or somewhere else, that's cool too.

title: RepRap I3 Prusa Infitary (hbi3) filament holder

description.text:
This is top holder for up to three filament rolls. It's dedicated for I3 Prusa Infitary hbi3 - Chinese brand, with LCD display and curved top frame.
Side stands are fixed both on front panel and side parts of the frame - so the weight of rolls makes printer even more stable. They are also shaped, to fit curved front panel design.

You need to print two (left and right) side stands, two blockers for sides of the horizontal bar. You will also need a 13mm horizontal bar and two 2mm screws. I choose 13mm metal, pipe - simply because I had such a diameter at hand.

title: Homo Naledi Complete Skull Reconstruction
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Named Homo Naledi, this new species of an extinct early human ancestor discovered by the Rising Star expedition team near Johannesburg, South Africa has stunned the paleoanthropology and archaeology world, and in true scientific fashion, they have published scanned specimens of their find and published on http://www.Morphosource.org for all to enjoy and participate in this extraordinary discovery. The original publication of this find can be found here:
http://elifesciences.org/content/4/e09560

For those of you not able to access the original scans, I have reconstructed the skull as was done in the paper by combining the fragments of specimens DH3 and DH4 to produce a replica skull found here:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1042872

In addition, I have also reconstructed the upper maxilla to match the published mandible and mirrored the zygomatic fragments; with these four files, I printed as much of the skull as possible, with the rest approximated based on skeletal landmarks of other early hominids. Sculpted clay finished the complete skull replication.

Enjoy and thank the awesome scientists who make this kind of reproduction possible. All specimens and original scans are attributable to the original authors. Scanned with NextEngine Scanner.

Contact information for this reconstruction:
Digital reconstructions done by Darryl R. Ricketts, M.S., Department of Sociology and Anthropology, Indiana University South Bend, email: [email protected]

Sculpting done by Susan M. Ward, Ernestine M. Raclin School of the Arts, Indiana University South Bend, email: [email protected]
Please attribute accordingly.

I am a forensic anthropologist NOT affiliated with this project or the Rising Star team. I teach anthropology and specialize in fetal osteology and 3D reconstruction. Please post a photo to share if you print this, and check out my other scans of skulls and bones at http://www.thingiverse.com/dricketts/designs.
Be sure to "Like" my Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/FetalReproductions to subscribe to my current prints/blogs, and see my Etsy page at http://Etsy.com/FetalReproductions for baby fetal scans, skulls, and other items to own.

title: Cord / Cable Coiler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The Cord / Cable Coiler is a small and simple solution to keep your power cords and Ethernet cables etc. tidy and make them easier to use and /mange during use. With the Cord / Cable Coiler your cords and cables will be stored in a neat and orderly way. In use, it lets you uncoil just the length required at the time then secure the rest of the cord / cable temporarily so it won't uncoil further.... then coil the length used up again after use. The design even has rails that are useful as handles to make it easy to carry your coiled cords / cables.

This makes keeping your cords and cables in order easy and also safer in use as excess cable is not left squirming around the floor where it could cause someone to trip and fall.

The size of the Cord / Cable Coiler has been kept to the minimum to perform their function well but without consuming too much filament to print (approx. 30gm. depending on version and print settings applied) and so they don't take too long to print.

Please note that a centre brace has been added to minimise distortion when the cord is wound on fairly tightly so the print will be slightly different from the images shown.

Size guide:

Large - 7.25mm to 7.5mm diameter power cords etc.

Medium: 6.25mm to 6.5mm diameter power cords and computer cabling etc.

Small: 5.0mm to 5.25mm diameter Ethernet / computer cables etc.

Cord / Cable Lengths: The length that can be coiled differs depending on the cord / cable diameter and how neatly / tightly it is coiled. However, they will all take at least 5M of cable. This means, as an example, if you have a 6M long cord / cable and only need about 3M for a specific purpose, just leave the remaining 3M coiled.

The Cord / Cable Coiler functions by separating the cable into two sections. Firstly isolate up to 1M of cable (short end) by clipping it into the centre retainers. The short end is the length of cable that, in the case of a power cord for example, is available to plug it into a wall socket. With the short end secured in the retainers you can coli it in the narrow coiling channel. Once the length is almost fully coiled in lock the end of the cable into the nearest end retainer on the narrow coiling channel side (Refer images).

Now you coil on the long end of the cord / cable by winding it neatly into the wide coiling channel. Coil from one side to the other, back and forth, When the free length is almost all coiled into the wide coiling channel lock the end of the cable into the nearest end retainer on the wide coiling channel side (Refer images).

Note: It is not recommended to coli cords / cables too tightly. Manufacturers of power cords in particular do not recommend using tightly coiled cables for extended periods due to the risk of heat build up etc.

The Cord / Cable Coiler is a practical solution for an every day problem. They are easy to print, don't use much filament and don't take too long to print... start getting your cords and cables under control today...

Please refer to the instructions and images for additional information.... and post images for others to see how your Cord / Cable Coilers are being put to use.

Note: If you like this check out he rest of my practical and fun designs!

Notes:

3 Shells and high infill is recommended to make the Cord / Cable Coiler springy and strong.

As there is a large range of cords / cables available on the market (including extension cords for power through to Ethernet etc.) three versions have been provided to accommodate most sizes.

If you find the version printed is slightly too loose of too tight in the areas the cable needs to be held securely (refer images) you can easily scale the file uniformly to suit. .

Using the Cord / Cable Coiler is easy...

Refer to the images... then start coiling up your cords and cables.

This is a way to temporarily mount a Primesense Carmine 1.09 (or, I guess a Carmine 1.08) 3D scanner onto a laptop.
The photos show a Carmine 1.09 mounted on an Acer S7 392 but different laptops can be accommodated by adjusting the height of the spacer in your slicing software.
The pegs in the front stop have small cross holes so the stop can be secured in place with a small piece of wire such as a staple, should that be considered necessary.
I've used 3 mm by 20 mm long button head screws to hold the assembly together, and a pair of compression springs to speed mounting and unmounting.
A shorter screw without springs works, too.
I did consider covering the faces that contact the laptop with blue tape but it doesn't seem to be required on the S7.

Nothing special. The orientation for printing is pretty self evident.
The support should be placed so that the 'tray' is in the vertical plane and pointing upwards. Similarly the front stop should have the pegs pointing upwards.

description.text:
I had a problem with my 3DSystems Cube 3 printer where the print plate would shift during prints. The print plate is held in place by 3 magnets which are supposed to hold it steady. However it is able to move slightly which will throw off your print job while it is moving quickly.

The solution was actually extremely simple and it shouldn’t void your warranty. I 3D printed 3 rings and used double sided tape to fix them to the bottom of the print plate. They fit perfectly over the magnets with no play and are not a tight fit. Since doing this, I get perfect prints even on tall objects.

There are many different double sided tapes you can use but the one I used (in the picture) sticks very well and won’t come off when you wash the glue from the plate.

I used PLA plastic, so if you use ABS, you may get different results.

Once you print the 3 rings, test fit them on the magnets to make sure they fit perfectly. They should slide over easily but not be snug. You should be able to pull them off with no resistance. If they have any play in them (too big), you will have to adjust the size and reprint them. I included the OpenSCAD file to make it easier. If they are too snug (too small), you should be able to sand down the inside a little. I used a dremel to get a perfect fit. If you use a dremel, put it on the slowest speed, otherwise the friction will melt the plastic. If you print this on something other than the Cube 3, you will probably have different results.

Once you are satisfied with the size, apply the double sided tape to the bottom of the rings and use an exacto knife to cut away the tape from the middle and outside. Make sure you don't leave any in the middle so it won't stick to the magnets.

Then place the rings over the magnets with the tape side up. Push them down low enough so the tape will not stick to the print plate when you place it on.

Put the print plate in place and make sure it is straight. I’m sure it doesn’t matter how straight it is. It just matters that it doesn’t move. But I’m OCD so…

Once the print plate is exactly where you want it, reach under and push the rings up onto the print plate.

Remove the print plate and push on the rings to make sure they are securely stuck on.

That’s it! The print plate should go on and come off easily and there will be no shifting during printing.

comments.text:
Also, if you use a pen and paint a "clock" on the rings, you can easier tune the bed when the Printer tells you to move 1/4, 2/4 etc each ring.
aka sort of this: http://cubifyfans.blogspot.com.es/2015/02/3d-printed-cube3-print-table-leveling.html
Perhaps you can modify your files, make the rings a lil wider and add such reference marks? :D
comments.author: bolsoncerrado

comments.text: Just a comment on this: if you print the rings on flex filament and scale them down, say, 99.5%, im pretty sure you can save up the double tape and the nature of the flexible filament will get even better stabilization against the plate.
comments.author: bolsoncerrado

comments.text: Unless someone has another 3D printer besides the Cube 3, they won't be able to print with flex filament.  And if not double sided tape, how would you fasten the flex filament to the print plate?

description.text: This is a design I did in Solidworks 2014 in order to get a more comfortable grip on my Glock 26 when using Glock 17 Magazines with it. This piece slides onto a 17 magazine and then when it is inserted into the 26 it matches up to the finger grooves in the front and the back radius is extremely close to the back strap radius. The one that I printed I inlaid a N on the left side of it. I have removed this for the file I uploaded here. I had four prototype prints before I got to this design and I think it works really well. It is rather snug on the magazine especially if your printer prints smaller than expected so you may have to file it somewhat on the inside. I wanted a tight fit on the magazine therefore I made it as tight as I could for my printer. Any Questions just let me know. Thanks.

comments.text: I have a new A8. I actually printed this non-remodded one and found out it was too large. Just put a piece of paper folded in 3 in between, and it fits (and the paper actually protects the frame against the aggressive plastic from the print). I actually plan to add some rubber foot inside for it to stay in place, otherwise it tends to move away as the acrylic frame is very slippery (and you risk harming it with a raw print directly on it). But I guess if I had seen and printed the remod, I would have used it as is. :)

comments.text:
Well, if you are the only one to complain, probably the distance is correct and you are using it in the wrong way, or your printer is not set properly.
Seeing your make, you use it on the top horizontal frame that is thinner than the vertical frame.
comments.author: alexan9er

comments.text: The distance is correct, but it doesnot fixes enough! Can you move it sides easily or it needs some force? My dont needs. The top plates are of the same thickness
comments.author: papinist

comments.text:
The original Anet A8 has different thickness between vertical and horizontal top frame. The top frame is thinner so and the filament guide won't stay on that.
Your printer is probably a different version, or a newer A8 with different parts!
comments.author: alexan9er

comments.text:
Ok, lets check. What is the desired distance in your model? I have 7.7 mm thickness for horizontal plate and 7.6 mm for vertical. I doubt whether they can be different due to the fact they were made from the single acrylic piece. The thicker acrylic is used for Z-motors side supports.
And what are yours dimensions?
comments.author: papinist

comments.text: As you can see, I only remixed this thing from an existing one. I moved the ring from vertical to horizontal without doing any measuring. Mine fits tightly on vertical frame and will slip and come off on the top horizontal frame. I don't have my printer at hand now so I can't take the thickness.

description.text:
Based on the Steam link design. For those that use a Raspberry Pi as a Steam link device.
More info on Pi streaming: https://www.raspberrypi.org/forums/viewtopic.php?t=65878&p=483479
I have this running on my Raspberry Pi B with a LAN cable to my router and a GTX970 PC card via powerline ethernet. Works a treat.

More about the Steam link here: https://www.engadget.com/2015/10/15/valves-steam-link-review/

The Pi B version has a small gap at the back for you to run the USB power cable through.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

CTC/Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

If the lid legs break when trying to fit onto the lower case, try increasing the infill and shaving/sanding off some off the legs to fit easier.

I used the frame built here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1153791 as a guide to building the design.

The bottom case frame for the Raspberry Pi B version I got from here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:608169

The bottom case frame for the Raspberry Pi 3 I got from here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:559858

This is a fatshark module door for the laForge V1.6 internal mod. I don't intend to make an external door version so feel free to remix this. Also I wasn't looking to make money off of these doors so I made my own. I got inspired by Thing:1498439. As you can see this is supposed to be as tight of a fit as possible. I would suggest adding hot glue once you're finished installing everything.

Solidoodle

Solidoodle 3

Yes

Yes

100%

title: Hype bluetooth headset around-ear adapter cups

description.text:
On-ear headsets may be very cost effective, but are very uncomfortable after about one hour of wearing them. I bought this $20 dollar Hype set and then designed some ear cup adapters so that I could wear them indefinitely. Go to Lowe's (or whatever hardware store) and plunk another 4 bucks on some foam backer rod and, voila... you just saved yourself a bundle of money by printing your own over-ear bluetooth headset! Nice.

Here's the assembly vid:

https://youtu.be/TTK4ELgyrSI

And here's a vid of the headset in question (HY-10588):

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ykNjSsHNRps

If you found this useful, please share your work and be sure to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

Sept 15th, 2016 update: Added a cushion for the top so that your poor pointy head doesn't have to suffer:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1773052

Oct 21st, 2016 update: Added a couple ear-specific cups (left and right) that have an extra 'tilt' which makes them a bit more ergonomic.

author: 3E8

description.text:
This will be my first upload. Originally thrown together a while back. We found it frustrating to make the small paper cones to tape down against plastic cups in order to create these small traps. Random heat waves here result in fruit flys/drain gnats. This provided us a reusable, washable, tool.

PRINTING:
This file was printed on my Ultimaker 2+.

Material: PLA
Print Speed: 75
Nozzle Size: .04
Temp: 215
Shells: 2

This piece was designed to fit snuggly over the lip of a generic clear plastic cup. Best results we've found was to place two drops of common dish soap and a small amount of apple cider vinegar roughly 10mm from the bottom of the cone.

Hope helps someone out, thanks for checking it out. Any suggestions/comments are welcome.

I wanted to do some time-lapse recording of 3d printing. I thought it might be nice to have a clock in the background, to give a sense of time expended. Of course, I could have just gone out and picked up a cheap clock, but where's the fun in that? I had this old iPhone 4 with a cracked screen that has been laying around for quite a while. So I installed a clock app, disabled all the other iPhone features and made some mounts.

If you find a good (or better) reason to mount an iPhone 4 to the wall, then here ya' go!

title: Black and Decker Single Source 18V Battery Template

description.text:
This is just a template for the top of a Black and Decker "single source" 18V NiCd battery. You could print it, but it is only for reference to make other objects. I included the step, stl, and FreeCad source files. It has a moderate amount of tolerance built into it, so you may want to be careful. The 18V key is really 4.2mm not 7 and the slot groove is really like 100mm not 105, but if you are trying to make a holder, or adapter, you should be fine.

I need a template for a skil 18V NiCd battery pack if anyone has one....

print_settings.Notes:: There are two ways to print this.  The first is to use removable supports for both arms, which I personally have not tried.  The second method is to cut off the first 1mm or so of the model (I use the z offset option in Simplify3D) so that all pieces are touching the build platform.

description.text:
Somebody I worked with picked up a little plastic catapult made by Stratasys out of Ultem while at a conference. This is a similar catapult based on the same principles. It prints as a single piece and uses torsional windup of the the throwing arm axle as a spring. The second arm holds the throwing arm in the ready position and acts as the trigger. It can launch a small ball of paper quite a distance.

Intended for PETG and other relatively stiff but yet elastic (not brittle) materials.

This is a bit of a work in progress as I tweak cross sections and such.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I expect PLA and ABS will only give you a handful of uses before breaking with this design. Instead, I use PETG and so far I have been able to get over 100 uses without any damage and only minor permanent set (arm resting position has rotated maybe 10 degrees). I expect nylons would also work, although the spring force may be rather weak with the geometry I chose.

There are two ways to print this. The first is to use removable supports for both arms, which I personally have not tried. The second method is to cut off the first 1mm or so of the model (I use the z offset option in Simplify3D) so that all pieces are touching the build platform.

title: Geeetech Prusa I3 Pro X Axis Cable Chain

description.text:
Starting from the bernbout's work I made a cable chain also for the X axis: I used the tmorris9's Nema cover for the motor side, and the two holes in the printer side panel for the other end.

The simple version of sidemount results not aligned with the motor, so I made a new version with also cable holders. You must use two M3/10mm screws to fix it (#25 in the Geeetech package); please look at the pics for the cables position.

You can find two versions of the NEMA mount, internal and external (I prefer the last), and also the single pieces to glue together for an easier print.

For the chain pieces please use the original bernbout's files.

Note: I removed one side to the Nema support because it hits my GT2560 box.

• Tear off helper disks
  • Clean off any bits of cruft

• I took some measurement of the thickness of my white board, a size of the corner that felt right, and measured them with some calipers.
  • I drew a sketch of my idea in a note book
  • Designed it in Sketchup.
  • Exported to an STL file
  • Tilted in Makerbot app 45 degrees and made sure it rested on the "platform"
  • Added a couple of helper disks to the design
  • Saved as an STL from Makerbot app.

description.text: A toy that's cute and gruesome all at once in designer vinyl style, but with 3d printed sensibilities.

Li'l Grendel: Awwww Mom!  Why do I have wear this kid-suit for Hallowe-en.

The file was made to be approximately 114 mm high.  So if there is a scaling discrepancy within your printing software, now you know what it is supposed to be :)  Some people will also be able to print this out with reasonable detail at 2/3 of it's size.
The white one shown, was printed on an UP printer using .3mm layers with no support.  However, I printed an earlier version of this when I was testing it's printability using .4mm and it works nicely too.

title: Active Carbon and Hepa Filter assembly set

description.text:
More info to come.

This was inspired by RJ_Make. This Hepa/Active Carbon filter design attempts to reduce the high restrictions created by his design. More then a dozen parts are provided, giving a large variety of options. I have printed all of my test parts in ABS so as long as you know how to limit warping you should be ok, else use PLA or some other material that does not warp much.

Current supported fan sizes: 60mm, 80mm, 92mm and 120mm
Fan I used for testing was a Delta FFB0912EHE-F00, the higher the static pressure rating fan you use the better. I intend to test the 0.5" Carbon setup with standard PC fans and record results.

Update: I have been using a 1" Carbon body and a standard 90mm case fan without any issues for a while now, the fan seems to have no issue pulling air into the filter.

4 bases provided: 1 square with extended legs, 1 round, 1 raised with bridging/vents and a vertical mount set.
4 different heights for the Active Carbon Body have been supplied, recommend only using the 1/2" unless you have a very strong fan, which will be very noisy.
Manual rotation of the parts in your slicer will most likely be required. The Fan Grills, Fan Adapters and Active Carbon Body's should be printed upside down. The bases and the Hepa Filter holder should be printed right side up.

Needed Parts:
4 Fan screws
The Filters are Roomba 800 HEPA filters.
I have found fiberglass window/sliding door screen to work well at holding the carbon inside without to much mess.

Printer:

Makerfarm Pegasus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10-25%

Notes:

I recommend 1 perimeter and 20-25% infill for most parts except the Grate Grill, it should be solid.

If you do the larger carbon bodies in ABS I recommend a skirt to prevent warping.

comments.text: First off, awesome print. I'm using the 1/2" body with a 147 CFM fan as a re-circulation filter and I'm pretty pleased with the lack of smell. It would be nice if there was a version of this that screwed together instead of using rubber bands though, I'm currently using zip ties to hold it together as my build chamber gets quite warm.

comments.text: Ah, I need to fix the naming, for a 120mm fan you need the 2Filter120mmFanAdapter and the 2Filter120mmFanAdapterTop.  You will need to secure the fan to the 2Filter120mmFanAdapter(I need to rename to 2FilterActiveCarbonBodyLid_120mm_Adapter to match the rest) using screws.  The version in the first picture was a screw-less design I created but it used more material/time and required an extra part which was not feasible with the larger fans.

description.text:
Thumb Screw heads for 10-32 Machine Screws. I made these to hold the battery cover of my Sensor Array project:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1670541

The screw is threaded into these heads and the tops are filled with epoxy.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Notes:

These are printed in PLA.

I ran a tap though the hole, then threaded the screw into the hole so the top of the head is inside the hex void.

The void is filled with epoxy. I taped the screws upright to the edge of a table until the epoxy was set up.

Let the epoxy cure, then they are ready to use.

I measured the screw and modeled the screw. The outside edge has a texture to make the head easier to grip. The head fits inside a void in the center so epoxy can be filled inside over the screw head. When the center is filled with epoxy, it will lock into the screw driver slot on the top of the screw. The inside void is a hex shape so the epoxy core will not spin.

As always, I have included the 123D Design file so you can modify the file. The 123D file includes the screw blank.

author: PaoloRob

title: ROLLER RING | Parametric Filament Spool Holder

description.text:
The spool roller is the ideal platform for simple, low cost, light, convenient and effective filament spool mounting. It is easy to build with minimal hardware, requires minimal effort to mount and dismount spools and takes up minimal space. This design was motivated by the basic simplicity and efficiency of the roller configuration while trying to address the inherent weaknesses in existing designs.
Improvements and Key Features
  • Fully parametric allowing complete control of all options from minimal lightweight to reinforced designs supporting virtually any spool size
  • Ring structure provides better stability with minimal filament and if using ABS, suffers less print warping compared to straight edges
  • Optional retainers prevent spool dislodging when weight reduced and allow mounting at any angle
  • Inner flanges on bearing holders negate the need for washers on the base
  • All parts can be printed apart from bearings
  • Spools can be changed quickly without tools

Alter the required values using the Customizer or editing directly in OpenSCAD. The minimal configuration without retainers requires 4 bolts and nuts and 4 bearings. All parts are printable except the bearings.
If using the optional retainers, threaded rod can also be added between the retainers with 2 bearings to secure the spool at any angle. I have included printable substitutes for metal 8mm nuts, bolts and threaded rod that print well. See NUT JOB | Nut, Bolt, Washer and Threaded Rod Factory http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647 for more info.
I recommend using at least 40% fill for the base and 100% fill for the nuts, bolts and threaded rod.
Note: The ring style base will require a slightly larger build area than a radial design.

title: Micro 4/3 to Pentax K Mount Adapter

description.text:
This part was designed to make use of a Pentax-M f1.7 50mm lens with my Panasonic G7. I have spent hours refining the dimensions, it is finely tuned. Your printer may vary :(

Included are Inventor 2017 part files, STLs, 100% infill region files, IDW drawings, and PDF Drawings.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

1.75mm PLA on PrintrBot Simple Metal 2015 with E3Dv6 Hotend, Mic6 Heated Bed, Kapton Tape. Use 40% infill, in Slicer apply Region Modifier .STLs as 100% infill regions. USE HIGH-OPACITY BLACK FILAMENT, light colors will not block ambient light, this will distort image.

Step 1: Cleanup

Cleanup both parts, remove sharp edges, and cut out drooping bridge filaments. Then test fit both parts into their respective mounts, they should be smooth but snug. Then fit the parts together, sanding/cutting as necessary.

Step 2: Align Lens

You must fine tune the correct "flange focal distance". Mount to tripod and set up looking at a scene with sharp features at infinity focus (e.g. the moon, skyscrapers, mountains). Set lens to infinity focus and then slide the forward mount until the far-away objects are in perfect focus. Apply a few drops of super glue to the outer seam to hold it there. Make sure the lens is square to the body flange and triple check your focus.

Step 3: Glue

Reinforce with more glue, apply a generous amount of 2-part epoxy to inside and outside seams. As it sets I would check that focus has not shifted. As it dries, use a finger wet with alcohol to smooth around the seams. Let cure for 24 hours.

Step 4: Finish

Sand inside and outside surfaces (don't deform the mounts!). Paint inside with matte black spray paint (to prevent reflective distortions). Try to get as matte and as dark as possible. Paint outside if desired.

This is an old magic trick. Put in a quarter and slide it into the disappearing coin trick and - 'Abra Cadabra' - it's gone! Slide it in again and it's back! Magic!

I used pink to show details better - use a black or dark filament to hide the 'magic'.

Note: Print the slide first and trim to size. Then when printing the 'Inner Box' at about 80mm or so, pause the print and slide the 'slider' in so it is captive.

Put the finished slide into the 'inner' box at about 80mm or so.

Real-time assembly and finish.

Trim the slide. It has to go into the inner box while it is being printed.
The inner box end holes may need to be trimmed so that the plunger in the outer box will fit.
All of my sliders have been snug and work well if yours does not and is too loose, try a bit of silicone glue at the coin separator on the slide.

title: Toyota/Lexus 3 Button Remote Key Case/Shell
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Dad recently noticed that the plastic of both of the keys for his car had cracked, and asked if I could print a replacement. "Sure, people have already made these, I've seen it"
Well, there were some great designs on here that almost did the trick, but I had to make a few adjustments to make it work with Dad's car. The Panic and unlock buttons are symmetrical, so adding that hole was easy. I had to shorten the case and let the metal key stick out a further 1.5mm. This almost certainly makes the case weaker, but otherwise the key could not push far enough into the ignition lock when turning the car off which made it very difficult to remove from the car.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed in black ABS with 5 shells/100% infill for max strength.
Print the top, and then choose between the branded and unbranded bottom halves.

Most of the holes will need to be drilled out, and some sanding and polishing or even acetone treatment may not be a bad idea.

I used 4 M3x6 screws to hold the case together, and I stripped out the head of the original tiny screw that came from the original key/wanted more strength anyway so I replaced it with an M2x8 screw from the hardware store (I didn't write down the thread pitch, but you can look that up online/it was literally the only M2 screw they stocked)

print_settings.Notes:: I printed mine in PETG so it can withstand a lot of abuse.

description.text:
It's fishing time!

Here are a few different basket designs for mounting to a sand spike / fishing pole holder. I made the bottom mesh to allow water and sand to get out. Now get out and fish!

I included a thin model for the curved one with the divider for fast printing. I printed it with a .6mm nozzle at .3 layer height. Takes less than 3 hours. I do not think PLA would hold up, but PETG feels like a thick Pepsi bottle and is very flexible.

Another update:
I added a curved one for 2" OD PVC in case you are using home made spikes. I have not tried it since all of mine were purchased and have an outside diameter of 48mm. I was assuming on the 2" one that the outer diameter is actually 2". Good luck!

I also included the solidworks file for one of them so you can edit it any way you want.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Does not matter

Infill:

55% but should not matter

Notes:

I printed mine in PETG so it can withstand a lot of abuse.

This is a three axis gimbal I have built many times over the last few years. It is simple to put together and for the most part bullet-proof. The parts list includes the following:

Prints
Mobius_Gimbal_Mount_Plate_v03.stl
Mobius_Gimbal_Side_Plate_01.stl
Mobius_Gimbal_Roll_Arm_v01.stl
Mobius_Gimbal_Yaw_Arm_v01.stl
Yaw_Motor_Base_v02.stl

Motors
3x RCTimer GBM2804 hollow shaft gimbal motors

Hardware
12x M3 x 8mm_SHCS
12x M3 Flat Washers
10x M3 x 6mm_FHPS

The dimensions of the printed parts are set to accommodate a Mobius with a C2 lens. The motors are a bit over-sized which is good if you are mounting on a plane. The motors also have a hollow shaft so that wiring can be neatly routed.

For a controller I would recommend the Storm32 3-Axis controller.

comments.text: Is it possible to do this but for an iPhone? thx a lot, David
comments.author: stolt

comments.text:
Hi David,
Yes and Probably No
Yes - you can build or buy a brushless gimbal that works with a smartphone. Here is one you can buy as an example:
https://www.amazon.com/LanParte-HHG-01-Motorized-Stabilizer-Smartphones/dp/B00OXMSZG2
Building would require a lot of redesign because the lengths of the arms is critical to balancing the gimbal. You would have to come up with a new mount that would hold the phone and the motors I show might not be strong enough for a device that is so heavy relative to a GoPro or Mobius camera.

description.text:
A case for Next Thing Co.'s C.H.i.P. (CHIP). It is designed to make room for a ~8 to 9cm heatsink attached to the CPU, which is located on the bottom of the board. Total thickness of the case is roughly an inch.

There are vents on the bottom of the case (since the heatsink goes down there). Therefore, I suggest printing and using the feet for the bottom of the case. Simply attach them with super glue.

The case snaps together as-printed, but a screw hole is present if you want the case to be held together more securely. Either use a long enough wood screw, or glue a washer to the top half of the case.

title: Belted Extruder v.3 for 1.75
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have released: Belted Extruder v4

Belted Extruder V.3 for 1.75mm

There are 3 versions here.
Two for m6 thread push-fittings (with and without support) and one for 1/8BSP thread.

I have made a Belted Extruder V.3 for 2.85mm as well.

If you are looking for a direct-drive (still geared with belt) I have made a Direct-Drive Belted Extruder 1,75mm V2 compatible with Prusa.

Brackets etc.
Everything for my Belted Extruders, including Mounting brackets can be found in the my Collection: Belted Extruders by Dintid.

  • You do not have to open idler to load filament, which makes it very easy to change filament!
  • Silent running due to belt operation
  • Higher accuracy and longelevity due to aluminium gears instead of printed gears.
  • Build in mount points on 3 sides. Compatible with standard Nema 17 brackets - 31mm mount hole distance from center to center.
  • I have succesfully printed using Shore D40 and D60 Flexibles, where number denotes softness. Pure Ninjaflex (shore A 85) does not work due to bowden.
    * Read wiki: Shore durometer if interested.

Details

  • I use a 60-GT2 aluminium pulley to avoid inaccuracies and avoid wear and tear of printed gear.
  • I am using a 16-GT2 Pulley for my small gear, which gives a ratio of 1:3.75
  • If you use a 20-GT2 Pulley for small gear you get ratio 1:3
  • Belt needed 172mm/86 teeth - 188mm/94 teeth
  • A Nema 17 motor - I use a small 0.9 steps pancake motor.
  • Belt is tightened by sliding motor away.
  • Strongly advice you to buy Hobbed Bolt from E3D - you can also buy it from Filastruder if that is easier for you.
  • Push-Fitting with m6 thread
  • With 32 microstepping and normal 1.8 degree Nema, the steps are about 1100mm/s filament, so ultra high definition and high torque

BOM

  • 60GT-2 Pulley
  • 16GT-2 or 20GT-2 Pulley
  • E3D Hobbed Bolt - Hobb-Goblin-8mm-Shaft
  • A belt with length between: 172-GT2 to 188-GT2.
  • Note: 200-GT2 is too long.
  • 2x m6 Push-Fitting for 1.75mm filament
  • 2x 20mm steel springs. 1mm thick
  • 2x m3 50mm (or longer) Partially Threaded Socket Head Cap screws
  • 3x 608 bearings. 8x22x7 - Type doesn't matter.
  • Various m3 nuts, screws and spacers

Nema 17 used
I am using Nema 17 "pancake" as in flat model.
Manufacturer Part Number: 17HM08-1204S
0.9deg Nema 17 Stepper Motor 1.2A 11Ncm/15.6oz.in 42x42x20mm
It's plenty to drive this, and I am currently using it to pull filament from a huge 2.3kg roll of filament.
You can ofcourse use bigger motors, but I rather like this model for it's compact size and great accuracy.
I found it on german ebay.

Printer:

My Crossbot design

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

44 or higher

Notes:

Print files as oriented.

  • I printed using 0.4mm nozzle
  • I used normal PLA
  • 3 Perimeters/Borders
  • 3 Top and Bottom layers
  • Use a strong Infil like Triangles in Cura 2.3
  • All necessary supports are build in
  • Use 44% infill or higher.
  • Do not make weak finger-release parts

Brackets for my Extruders

I've made a Collection named Belted Extruders by Dintid where all my items related to my Belted Extruders is going to be added.

Please let me know if you need a special bracket.
Remove supports colored red here.
Tested ok using 172-GT2 to 188-GT2. 200-GT2 is too long.

Use some painters tape or similar if the bearing is wobbling when assembled, which it most likely does. If your bearing sits loosely, try downloading <h3>Calculate steps/mm</h3>

A few stepper examples. Remember to do a proper measurement yourself. I have rounded the numbers up/down.

When using:

  • 16-GT2 + 60-GT2 pulleys + 1/32 multistepping + 0.9degree motor = 2050 steps/mm
  • 16-GT2 + 60-GT2 pulleys + 1/16 multistepping + 0.9 degree motor = 1025 steps/mm
  • 16-GT2 + 60-GT2 pulleys + 1/32 multistepping + 1.8 degree motor = 1025 steps/mm
  • 16-GT2 + 60-GT2 pulleys + 1/16 multistepping + 1.8 degree motor = 510 steps/mm
Do not skimp on Hobbed Bolt. Right one is E3D.. other one is from respectable local shop... Just go E3D.

comments.text: These belted extruders are amazing! I just finished printing mine, and I'm about to adjust the steps/mm. I don't know why this isn't more popular in the 3D Printing community, but I'm definitely sold.
comments.author: Ajnordin

comments.text:
Amazing job!
Do you think it will be possible to make a NEMA17 adapter utilizing this principle so we can drive the Flexion with a pancake ? That would be awesome .. I was thinking it should be similar to this design but instead of the goblin bolt, use a 5mm DIN7 / ISO 2338 pin, though they seem to have max standard length of 60mm - not sure if it will be enough .. and I am considering such a pin as it self fastens to a 5mm bearing bore, which an M5 bolt does not... .
comments.author: Pumpal

comments.text:
Hello Pumpal - Thank you for your nice words! :)
I don't know the "Flexion"?
I have thought about designing a model using 5mm bore but it brings other challenges like smaller bearings = more risk of flexing/bending the extruder as there is less support for the drivebit and wheel. Also requires existing users to buy new drivebits and wheels etc :)
comments.author: Pumpal

comments.text: Honestly, if I knew about your work, I would probably never purchase a pre-made extruder  - collected, and definitely top of the list for any upcoming build.. especially this V4 that you pointed to - looks super neat .. !
comments.author: dintid

comments.text: Can you make a double gear drive?

Why?
I thought about it.. way back, before I made my first working prototype... but it's totally overkill. I drive these things using small 1.1kg/cm torque motors. I even print semi-flex in 40cm bowden tubes.

Today I built one of these, looking good, but the steps calculation drives me crazy and the prints look like crap.
My printer is a Hypercube Evolution with an E3D V6 Clone as bowden extruder. I am using Marlin firmware, and until now, my value of steps/mm was 95 and printed nicely. Well why did I change then? Because my extruder motor got pretty hot in times (46nm version) and a geared extruder needs less motor power.
And according to Triffid Calibration guilde, my steps/mm calculation looks like this:
comments.author: Biggsis

comments.text:
Well, I have to admit, it was pretty much my own fault, as I found out. Whatever I tried in the Marlin firmware, I had a false value in the EEPROM and THAT value was used all the time, no matter what I flashed. So the EEPROM has priority over the flashed firmware if there is a value stored.
So just forgive me for whining, entirely my bad....
comments.author: Biggsis

description.text:
This is a baroque oboe modified to modern pitch. Its appearance is based on a baroque oboe in the Boston Museum of Fine Arts Collection.
The oboe consists of 3 sections, namely upper joint, lower joint and bell. To fit into my RepRap's printable area, upper joint and lower joint are divided by two parts. Each bonding surface of these parts is created 1mm bottom up and two alignment holes. You need to shave the bottom up of the bonding surface before you bond together.

Update - Sep. 15th, 2016
The oboe has two keys which are made from a 1.5mm brass sheet.
A drawing of them is added(keys_rev2.pdf). You may need to arrange or adjust for your instrument.

comments.text: How large is the final product?
comments.author: mudface2003

comments.text: I am in the process of making this oboe for my daughter. She is taking a master in modern oboe and also working on the Baroque. While she waits for her instrument to get made, I figured I would give this a shot and surprise her.
comments.author: fll_freak

comments.text:
I have printed this oboe (baroque oboe at 440Hz pitch) successfully at home, in black PLA, 20% infill, without supports at all.
Some pin holes were a little bit nasty, but I corrected it by passing a soldering iron very gently into it to get the round shape back.
I have designed and print the 2 keys in PLA too, but it could be done in PETG to get a better strength.
With 20% infill, you get a good resonance: https://photos.app.goo.gl/UqUZSHYXxGLGfdtH2
Beware that the baroque oboe which is being made is certainly in 415Hz pitch, while this present model is smaller and is 440Hz pitch. This means that the present 3D printed model will sound higher than the one she will receive when the instrument maker has finished his artistic work.
Concerning the joints, it was the most tricky part. I had to sand the joints a lot to get sufficient place to glue a piece of cork around the joint.
comments.author: fll_freak

comments.text:
Thanks for the reply. I have been working on this off and on for a while. I have been printing this a few times and have decided that the bottom joint with the key work needs to be designed in several parts. As is, my printer does a terrible job with support materials and will not print the overhangs. So the second ring I am printing as a separate piece to glue in afterwards.
I purchased replacement pads from eBay that might do the trick. I am now looking at what to use for the pins. I am thinking of some 0-56 bolts. The shank is smooth and I would cut off the head and slot the rod for a screw driver. But even a 0-56 is pretty big in diameter. What did you use for pins?
I am also building a small special purpose lathe for the sole purpose of reaming out the bore. Musical friends have told me and roughness in the bore would impact the sound. I am also experimenting with the XTC-3D epoxy coating. So far I find it a bit thick and I am looking for a thinner for it. That might solve the rough bore issue.
I have no illusion that this instrument will compete with the oboe my daughter just ordered, but it would be worth a laugh to pull out a purple oboe to 'play' at a rehearsal.
I will try to add more notes as I continue this build.
comments.author: croisez

comments.text:
For holding the two keys to the body of the instrument, I have used sewing pins, from which I have cut the slender part.
If you need it, I can send you the STL models of my keys.
About the overhangs issue, I have used the "Slic3r" application to produce the g-code. I find it very efficient in case of severe overhangs, because it exploit greatly all capacities of my Prusa i3 clone: varying the printing speed to allow the plastic to cool more, using full speed fan.
I personally would go preferably to such solution, and not to printing this part in several pieces. I think that glueing could bring matter anisotropy that could influence the quality of the sound of this instrument.
As concerns the quality of the sound, yes of course, the bore is rough, and it is definitely a big issue. But, as you can hear on the video I referenced in my previous post, the result is quite acceptable for such a toy.
I have found a reference on the web where you could order a 3D-printed baroque oboe in 415. It is from Italy: https://dragoncornett.jimdo.com/instruments-1/baroque-oboe/
Perhaps it could be a better idea for your daughter. Personally I did not ordered this 3d-printed instrument because the price is too high (~450€) for me considering I am not a professional. But as your daughter is a (future) professional, it could be a better solution that printing it yourself.
comments.author: fll_freak

comments.text: I am relatively new to the 3D printing world so what settings would you reccommend to print this. I plan to play it as an experiment into baroque oboes. I have a full keywork on my intermediate oboe so this will be a fun and interesting challenge!

description.text:
Mold to make silicone boots for the Flashforge Creator Pro 2016.

I've made the silicone boots out ordinary 2 part silicone mix to get the mold right, but have ordered high temp silicone mix to make the final boots: http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/262190021883?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

The boots are designed to keep the nozzle heads clean.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro 2016

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print in ABS, then acetone vapour the parts. The silicone will not stick to the shiny surface.

Fill the base half full with your silicone mix, then slowly and carefully push the top down into the base. The excess will come out around the edge and also up though the vent holes.

I've used stainless wire to 'squeeze' the base and top together, but you could use rubber bands or cable ties around the recesses on the base and top.

To be sure you have the base and top the correct way round, make sure the grooves on the outside of each part are on the same side when pushing together.

description.text: I designed this bracket to use with my TEVO Black Widow 3D printer, but it could be useful for any project using V-Slot extrusions. I am using these brackets in conjunction with aluminum L plates, but I included holes and space for T-nuts so they could be locked in place themselves.

Print with angled side on bed as in the STL. No supports needed. Use raft/brim as needed for your printer/filament. I suggest 0.25mm layer height or less if using standard 0.4mm nozzle.

It might take a little "finesse" to insert it into the v-slot the first time, but once you insert it and slide it a bit the fit is snug but not too tight to move around.

description.text:
A little cube I put together using OpenSCAD

I print using a makergear m2 and noticed a lot of things I've tried printing from thingiverse fail anytime I try and use an overhang without supports. I wanted to see if prints from OpenSCAD may fair better and was very surprised when this thing worked.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I got this to work using a 10% infill. It was semi flimsy, but it printed the whole thing.

I imagine upping the infill would make for a much more solid cube.

I've not tried this with ABS

The idea was to make a shower drain hair catcher, but I was really just screwing around SketchUp. Diameter should fit (40 mm across), but I make no guarantees about the printability of this object or anything else, really.

Also sharing the original size as just an "art piece."

09/11/2016: Tested and failed. Does not catch hair as planned, but it was still fun to learn a few new tricks in SketchUp. Back to the drawing board.

When creating objects, I often found I needed to reprint as the plastic printed was not exactly the correct size.

I have created a set of size jigs for PLA and ABS plastic in 0.25 mm increments . These are both pins and holes and can be attached to a key ring.
Holes are handy for selecting screw sizes, and the pins are handy for selecting the correct size if you need a pin to fit in a hole.

I used a "Paint Marker" with the point on its side to mark the increments over the embedded sizes.

description.text:
This is a heart base I created where you can add engraving (before printing). I engraved, printed this in Hatchbox Wood+PLA filament, sanded, stained and added acrylic. (Having never worked with wood (even real) before, this seemed to turn out really well).

I detailed the process in the Post-Printing section with pictures.
I detailed how to engrave in the How I Designed This section.

Everyone I showed this to believes it's wood and wonders how I engraved so perfectly ("with a computer, right? but how?"). They are surprised that it was 3d printed. My wife (who this gift was intended for) took ~15 seconds to realize this was 3d printed - a record long time for her - possibly also due to not believing I could actually burn/engrave wood.

(note: don't expect to print wood, then engrave by burning... the PLA+wood filament would only melt, not burn).

Good luck - hope to see what you produce.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1984mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

added a brim - probably didn't matter

Yep, it's printed wood (mostly). Awesome. Ok, those letters were too small. Along with my Simplify3d settings (and maybe all of them), the filament got strung over/bled over the words. LOTS of sanding and metal-tooth-picking each letter later, it looks better. FUTURE NOTE: always sand in lines (left/right) so that later staining follows the sanding lines. Stained once all over. Those odd scuff marks are my using a dremel to sand and not in the same directions. Staining highlights all errors. I want those awesome natural-wood stain lines. IDEA: let the 2nd staining just drip down each line between the words. Then wipe off in the same direction. Totally worked. New stain lines visible. Also, using a darker (near black) stain for the edges. Acrylic applied once and wet. Acrylic applied 3rd or 4th time (30 minutes dried each time in front of a purifier fan to avoid dust). Final - day later - 4th acrylic coat dried. 1st attempt at this - really looks and feels amazing.

Text Engraving Steps

The following steps show how to engrave text into an object. It's by default easy to add text as a solid or merge, however, to indent, it takes a few more steps.

A few specifics: The object height is ~11mm. I create the text at 10mm and sink it 5mm deep. The depth helps for the staining to get in and make it darker. (It also makes the printout take much longer as it has to handle text details for half the object).

The bigger and bolder the text, the cleaner the letters will be. Really small and cursive fonts won't indent well as the filament bleeds over during printhead travel.

Use the 'T'ext tool and add text on the heart. Center, etc. Select the text (sketch), click the gear button, and the Extrude Text button. Extrude up beyond how much you will indent. This is to get a handle later if needed. REMEMBER to select Solid (circled in red), not (default) Merge. After extruding 10mm (as an example), I moved it 5mm down into the object (half the object height). Select the Subtract tool (circled). Then select the heart/object, then the text and click on the background. The text will be subtracted from the heart. The original Text sketch is still there and needs to be deleted. Select and delete. The result is an indented set of text.

title: HTC Vive Controller Gun Rail Mount

description.text:
If you're making a gun for Onward I would recommend Gwinntanamo's design instead.
https://youtu.be/u60bpVQV-AE <-- Original Gwinntanamo design
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1776502 <-- My 3D printed version

I'll leave this design here for academic purposes but I won't be updating it any further.

Credit to the previous designers without whom I would not have even started.

I remodeled the controller attachments so that they can't slip when you're pulling the gun back in to your shoulder. They easily slide off forwards.

Edit: A 30x30 length of wood is way too heavy.
I also used a 30mm x 30mm square length of wood to screw flat rail mounts on to so that I could print the rails without support.

Screw the gun rails on to a piece of wood with 18mm M3 wood screws.
Insert 2x 10mm x 2mm round rare earth magnets in each hole. Needs 8 magnets total. Use a hammer and small piece of wood to tap them in.
Attach to your controllers using a 25mm M3 Hex bolt and a nylock nut with washer.

description.text: Penny box to weigh down the Z-stage. This has improved my first layers of the print. Your mileage may vary though.
Print box, fill with 25 pennies and put at the back of the Z-stage. Use double sided tape to keep in place. I printed 4 of them as you can see in the picture.

comments.text: I am curious as to how or why you think adding weight to the rear of the z platform improves your first layers?
comments.author: M_G

comments.text: Seem to me that the platform get stuck a little bit and don't "fall down" to the lowest position. So the first layers seem to be squished since they are printed over and over. When adding the weight, it seem like the z stage fall down to it's lowest position. I also use 3-in-one oil on the Z rods and white lithium grease on the screw attached to the stepper. Hope this helps...
comments.author: M_G

comments.text: I initially had this problem with mine.  I removed the rods and flipped them over and rotated them while jogging the machine around making sure the bearings were well lubricated with 3-in-1 or Silicone Lubricant.  If you take the stepper with the screw gear out you should be able - without loading the platform - to pick it up to the top and release it - it should slide all the way to the platform without hanging up.  If it doesn't adjust and lube till it's right.  Reinstall the screw stepper and lightly fasten the screws and jog it up and down a couple times to make sure it's centered properly - if the screw bind after this then it might be bent.
comments.author: alamorobotics

comments.text: I'm waiting for my linear bearings, they should hopefully ship around the 24:th. That should hopefully take care of my Z-axis problems.
comments.author: UechiMike

title: Medium Sized Quadrocopter with damped electronic plates
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I used 8.8mm carbon fiber hose and the following RC components:

Spektrum AR400 receiver
Hobbyking NanoWii Flight Controler
Hobbyking Blue Series 12A ESC
Turnigy AX2204C motors
8x4 props.

The downloadable files are organized by the material you should use. Some important components must be made from flex. See the assembly-STL to get an overview how things are put together.

author: mm-cnc

title: Dimmable Night Light cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This dimmable night light is based on the "Mechanical iris v2.0" by NTT which was published at instructables. A ring can be turned to open and close the iris to dim the led below. I used a Ledberg Spotlight from IKEA, a cheap and economical lamp with a nice warm light.

The blades were made from 1.5 mm "airplane plywood", the other layers from 6,5 mm regular birch plywood using a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs. Consider a donation if you like the build.

author: ZenziWerken

description.text:
Ballon drop contraption for Crossfire 2.
You need M3 screws, some standoffs (mine are from ZMR 250), standard servo and some wire for a servo horn.

Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=drfwoMZkUVY

input is for 1/2 13mm inside diameter tube

probably best to print the printable version! and adjuste the outlet tubes to your preference in the scad file.

Best way to finish the piece is to put it in a jam jar, pour some very thin ABS juice all over it and inside all the holes and let it flow through, and then empty the juice back into the original flask, and you are left with a water tight plastic distributor.

To the blind, the outside of a 2L Diet Pepsi bottle, and a bottle of Lemonade look the same. There is nothing worse than a shandy made from beer and coke.

These re-usable labels clip around the neck of 2L PET bottles (Certainly the ones in UK and France), and contain brief labels to enable bottles to be distinguished from each other.

Notes:

I printed with ABS, as it is more flexible than PLA.
Print this one upside-down. There should be no need for supports.
For me, on the Davinci Pro, the print takes around 40 minutes for one, and 4 hours for 9.

Vapour Smoothing

I made some of these with, and without vapour smoothing.
I found that it was better not to smooth in this case, as the braille is a lot clearer.

Fully functional model cabin ropeway designed with Sketchup and printed with CTC printer. The cabins are rolling up and down on two ropes each. The moving rope is driven by a geared 12V DC motor and controlled by an Arduino Mega with Mosfet/PWM. The Cabins begin driving slowly, accelerate and drive constantly until reaching the station, where they slowly move in and finally stop. The movement is controlled by ultrasound sensors connected to the Arduino measuring the distance between the cabin and the station thus adapting the motorspeed.
Please download the sketchup file which contains all parts and extract them yourself.
Have fun constructing it!

Printer:

CTC

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Pirate sailing ship models remixed from OpenSCAD Pirate Ship, for use e.g. as boardgame pieces.

Features a bigger three-masted ship and a smaller two-masted ship. The models have been tuned so they should print nicely out of the box without supports.

Alternate versions of the ships feature a system of interchangeable flags; ships have a slot on the bridge deck that supports the included flags. Different colours and shapes of the flags can be used to distinguish between similar vessels of the same colour when needed, for example, in boardgames.

Should print fine without supports.

The flags should in principle fit into the slots at 100% scale. However, the fit can be quite tight, so you may have to trim extra material from the flags after the print or slightly downscale them for better fit.

This is a case to hold Arduino RAMPS v1.4 (and perhaps other versions) electronics. It is designed to sit atop a Prusa but I'm sure it can be easily edited to fit other needs. There are 4 feet which are inserted through the inside of the case and then they clip softly onto the top rails. I really like the way it came out, although I forgot to account for the wiring for the bed!
I also have a lid which accepts a 40mm fan designed but I haven't printed it yet - I'll upload it once I know it works.
This case has cutout for power and USB on the back and 3 cutouts where you can insert one each of 6-pin, 12-pin and 9-pin interlocking connectors from RadioShack. The idea is to allow for easy relocation, etc. (really I just like making things that are neat and clean).

1) Print the case and 4 feet.
2) Insert your female interlocking connectors from the inside of the case.
3) Insert your electronics, they should fit snug almost to the bottom of the case.
4) Wire everything up!

It should fit any i3 clone with a 6mm thick frame that uses 1.75mm filament.

Just print in PLA using whatever settings you like and it should come out just fine.

This is my first "Thing". The OpenSCAD code is pretty crude but it does the job.

Hope you like it.

title: Customizable License Plate Holder (US Motorcycle Sizing)

description.text:
Go ahead and click 'Open in Customizer' to make a motorcycle license plate holder with your own text!

This fits my American motorcycle license plates perfectly, your mileage may vary. (pun intended)

Notes:

No supports or anything fancy necessary.

I printed mine in PLA as a purposeful experiment in print biodegradability in harsh real-world conditions being outside in the rain and sun and unusual amounts of wind and vibration.
So far it's held up fine except for warping on an extraordinarily hot day (95F/35C) in the direct sun.

Would suggest you print it in whatever you can print that can take the heat better (ABS, some nylon filaments, etc)

I don't have a dual-extruder system, so I just painted my lettering with white acrylic.

I'm not an artsy painter by any means and it turned out great, because it was easy to paint the raised text and magically get crisp paint lines.

I've also included a variable in the customizer that spaces out the letters a tiny bit more, that should make them easier to paint and make it less likely that a not-top-of-the-line 3D printer would make a stringy mess between letters.
This is actually my first OpenSCAD project, specifically to allow customization!

title: Brake Wreath replacement - Baby Buggy Bergsteiger Venedig

description.text:
I have redesigned the orginal Brakewreath of a baby buggy (stroller).

The Baby buggy is called: "Bergsteiger Venedig"

The original replacement part was breaking all the time, so i redesigned the thing a little bit more sturdy with fewer arms.

This is the 7th iteration of the new design as the early models the little arms gripping the spokes were breaking off very easy. This version has very sturdy gripping arms.

The thing is the clearence of the spoke grippers is very tight so you would have to use a soft-head hammer to mount the wreath. If the fitting is to tight, you can tell me and i will widen the clearence a little bit.

Feel free to ask if you have any questions!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,25

Infill:

85

Notes:

I would def opt for higher infill because this has to be sturdy.

Eventhough if one of the brake wreath is breaking off you still have another for redundancy!

author: tracknet

description.text:
This is an adaptor to allow you to fit wheels on the back of your Lunchbox or Midnight Pumpkin that have 12mm hex drives.

The standard Lunchbox or Midnight Pumpkin wheels are a very unusual size and fitting type so finding decent tyres or hubs is almost impossible, with these adaptors lots of standard rc car hubs will fit.

Print upside down, with the 12mm Hex at the bottom, this allows for the small protrusion on the other side to be printed. The protrusion is needed to allow the adaptor to transfer axial loads into the out bearing rather than going through the diff gears.

title: Slap switch, safety switch for stationary power tools

description.text: This is a home made safety switch inspired by this web page: http://rick.sparber.org/ssw.pdf Where his is made from MDF, mine is 3d printed. I included the Solidworks 2011 files in zip format for those who can use them.

Print the two parts, assemble with two 6-32 screws 3/4 inch long, as in the photo. The holes should print for self tapping.
Mount to your Decora switch making sure it is right way up.
See the PDF in the link for more information.
Paint it or print it in red for the traditional safety switch look.

description.text:
Update Aug 2017: There is a new insert which I think is better than mine: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2151776
But I am not sure if the dimensions of the box are the same as the German box.

I hated it that all my tiles from Terra Mystica were thrown in the box. So I created these boxes for them. Every play has its own box. Also all the material needed to be beside the board is in extra boxes.

This is my first design and it is far from being perfect. Feel free to remix it. I have added the file for Autodesk Fusion 360.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Infill does not need to be 20% because there is not a lot to infill. If you want smoother boxes use a 0.1mm resolution.

Rotate all parts 90 degrees so they lay flat.

A few weeks ago I was for holidays on the USA and replaced my old Galaxy Note 3 by the brand new Galaxy Note 7. I try not to use cases so I came back home to Argentina with the phone only. A week passed and I broke the back glass and I have heard in the news I have to replace my phone for a new one because batteries are burning.
Replacement is not yet on the street so I waiting for it to send the phone back to the USA to be replaced. I hope the scratched glass not to be an issue.
In the meantime there are not cases for this phone in my country so I've decided to build a basic plastic case to protect broken glass and continue using the phone.
For you, the result. I hope you find it useful.

description.text:
Dingoboy71's remix of tamel55's filament spool is great and solved some slicing issues I had with the equally great original.

After printing it out, however, I noticed that there was something missing: guide holes to anchor either end of the filament to keep it from unwinding and getting tangled.

This remix adds that simple feature.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

15%

Notes:

The first one I printed was with 10% infill and it feels just a bit too low to get good top surfaces. 15% seemed a lot nicer for me.
I decided to experiment with OpenSCAD for this project and it worked great. I look forward to using it for other tasks and encourage others to look into it as well.

Dimension of SATA plug is 47x13mm

I could not find a perfect fit for an enclosure, so I designed it from scratch, making it as small and simple as possible. It can be used with or without the "back lid". The 4 side screws are used to keep the drive in place.

It prints with the SATA hole down. Supports for the bridges are included in the model, it breaks off easily after print. If you want to close the back opening, print the "lid" piece.

author: NOP21

title: Oneplus Two 3D model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 3D model of the Oneplus Two. I created it as a reference to design parts for it.
The doubly-curved geometry of the rear surface was the trickiest part to model, and it is as close as possible to the shape that I obtained through a 3D scan of the phone.

rev. 1: outer dimensions fixed. Small discrepancies still present, as the edges of the phone aren't straight but slightly angled...

Step 1: pictures for 3D model

I captured approx. 40 images of the back of the phone from different angles.

Step 2: 3D reconstruction

I loaded the pictures in Autodesk 123d Catch, and have it reconstruct the shape. All the magic is done in the Cloud...

Step 3: Load point cloud in CAD software

Thanks to the University I am studying at, I have access to CATIA.
Very few basic steps (good tutorials can be found in Youtube)

  • Shape => Digitized shape editor
  • => Import, to import OBJ mesh
  • => Activate, to select only the points on the back of the phone
  • Shape => Quick Surface Reconstruction
  • => Power Fit, to fit a surface on the selected points
Brown: surface from points cloud; yellow: fitted surface Step 4: model

I reconstructed, through splines, the top and bottom edges of the back side (1 and 1'). I added two additional intermediate segments, to better capture the curvature (2 and 2').
The lateral edges were simply straight lines (3 and 3') and, once more, to capture the curvature I added two additional segments along the height (4).
A Multi-Sections surface was then created over these lines.

I then extruded the body up to this surface, and added details (usb port, loudspeaker holes, side buttons...).

By comparing, in MeshLab, the reconstructed mesh and the 3D model, you can see a good match.

comments.text:
Great work, thanks a lot!
Any chance you might share the CATIA files (or a STEP file) instead only a STL? I'm designing a bumper for the OP2, and working from a mesh file is almost the same effort as working from a point cloud, as I first have to create a proper model from the mesh. If you think of it, most of your hard work actually is wasted that way!
comments.author: fgalore

comments.text:
Dear fgalore, thanks a lot for your comment and feedback!
Right, I didn't think of uploading a STEP file... that's going to be online really soon! I am not so sure whether the educational license of CATIA that my university has allows me to provide CATPart files, hence the lack of it.

title: E3DV6 bowden carriage from Tech2C double radial fan

description.text:
This is my Dual radial fan version based on Tech2C's awesome work
It helps a lot for people who have trouble with overhang on the opposite side of the blower fan, with tech2c's latest carriage.

Now I can print parts with large overhangs, with standard cura speeds (60mm/s).

I recommend using one or these to keep the heat block hot :
http://e3d-online.com/Socks-Launch

Just use 2x 50mm fans (from banggood)
Parts are easy to print without supports

you will need :

  • 2x M3 nuts
  • 2x M3x20 (min) screws
  • 2x M4x30 screws
  • Tech2c's E3D v6 Bowden X-carriage (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:547706)

Cheers !

comments.text: How can I protect the heat block? I mean, 2 powerful radial fans would probably cool the heat block, and to keep it hot it would take a lot of energy...
comments.author: PetersonM

comments.text:
First you should lower the air outputs as low as possible in order to blow air under the heat block. And set the max fan speed to 50-60%.
Then I bought one of those e3d silicone socks (it is really cheap) and it really protects the heat block and the nozzle from the cold air. So I can now blow at 100%. It is really working well with overhangs and higher print speed

title: Modular Wine Rack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: The modular winerack is designed for 6mm rigid material, such as whiteboard or MDF, but it can be tweaked for other material thicknesses. It is easy to assemble with no glue required to hold it together.  You can cut two sets and stack them on top of one another â€“ hence the â€œmodularâ€ rack.

The winerack comes with two types of connectors: narrow single slot for either top or bottom and wide double slot for connecting two modules together into a bigger winerack. Each module is designed to fit onto a sheet of material measuring 394mm x 790mm, and if you're making more than one module for stacking, you should delete the connectors off the second files, as they will be surplus. If you only want the one module, you should delete the surplus double slot connectors.
Gluing isnâ€™t necessary, however, keep this in mind when you decide to pick up the whole rack filled with bottles, by the top connector. If that sounds like something youâ€™d do, then you should probably glue the joins.
