author: Yana

title: Bits for Blackhawk lowboy 2 quad wheeled powered paraglider

description.text:
Some parts I made for my lowboy. It is surprising how many downloads this project is getting.
The aren't many quads around so people must be using the parts for something else.
Things
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:286361
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:283818
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:345156
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:283821
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:180997
are also for the quad. I'm building a quad PPG wihich is powered by a verner JCV-360 engine -AKA hellcat-360
It is fuel injected.
The enigine is monitored by a PPG-meter. I'm mounted the meter on the front right riser tube, I'm working on combining this with a phone holder.
The battery charging etc is controlled by a device marked "Fly Henry".
There is also an engine control unit.
I've mounted these back to back on a vertical tube behind the seat.
There is a 24V ni-cad pack for starting the engine etc.
I've mounted this on the rear right main frame riser tube.
This is a vertical tube - the photo is showing up rotated ATM.
I wanted to run the 9mm plastic fuel line along a 20mm steel tube.
Simply clamping it with zip-ties crushes the fuel line.
I made a little clip which does the job without the crushing.
A zip-tie goes around the clip to hold it in place.
Later - made one for 26mm frame as well. I use this for radiator overflow and fuel tank breather lines.
I made a clamp to attach the fuel pump to a 26mm tube.
This works OK but could be improved by having a narrow bit at the bottom to prevent the pump sliding down.
I will do a new version if this is a real problem.
I'm moving the pump onto a 29mm horizonatal tube. For this I've made fuelpumpclamp-29. It is half the height and I'll use two of them.
The tbarbholder is for mounting a fuel line T-peice on a 20mm tube. The oval holes are to hold a pair of zip-ties in place.
XT60 - Oct 2014
The quad's existing battery is totally inadequate for cold starts.
It can't supply enough power to crank plus run the fuel pump etc.
So I've added a socket to plug in a SLA pack for starting. I'm only feeding in 24V not the 12V centre tap.
I used xt60 connectors because they are cheap and have a high current rating (about 85A).
The socket on the quad is glued into a holder which is zip tied to a 25mm tube. The other xt60 parts are for the battery, charging lead and blank plug to keep dust etc out of the used sockets.
I tried including a cheap DVM into the charging socket but it failed - maybe another time. More info about my quad can be found here - http://eddiem.com/tikiwiki/tiki-index.php?page=Blackhawk+tandem+quad

All parts were printed in PLA with .4mm slices.
Holes for nuts are undersized to hold the nuts captive.
I had to heat some of the bits to get the nuts in.
The screws clamping the parts around the tubes are M3.
I may have to redo the designs to use nylocks.
The mounts screws for the flyhenry and ECU are M5

description.text:
This part couples a 5mm motor shaft of a 28BYJ-48 stepper motor to a 5mm threaded rod.

On the lookout for a motor coupling for the Cherry 60€ 3D printer, I could not find a suitable coupler for M3 screws (even though some designs claimed to be designed for M3).

The OpenSCAD file is a bit hacked, but usable, if you know what you're doing. Thanks to nophead and those before him for the design!

I printed this one in PETG, but it should work in PLA or ABS just as well.

remixed_from.author: Zalophus
remixed_from.title: Super Ultra Compact Pan Tilt Camera Mount - V1

title: 9g Hexapod Pi Zero Camera Updated Version

description.text:
This is a remix of Hardmouse's 9g Hexapod with Zalophus's Camera Mount. (Work in progress)

My ultimate goal is to make this autonomous (using S.L.A.M) but for now I'll just use facial tracking. This is kind of untested, I have printed and assembled the bot but haven't got the the point of coding/testing yet.

The last 4 servos are driven from the Pi. Use the hardware PWM pins (GPIO13 & GPIO18) for the legs and any other pins (software PWM) for the camera mount. (If you do this remember NOT to power them from the Pi)

Components required:
Raspberry Pi Zero v1.3
Pi Camera with Pi Zero Cable (cable is different to regular one)
Adafruit 16 Channel Servo Module Link.
20 x 9g Servos (I used Tower Pro SG90s)
Mini WIFI Dongle like this attached using this.
10 x M3 nuts & bolts
42 x m2 self-tapping screws (6mm)
9 x m2 nuts bolts 14mm
You will also need the mounting screws that came with your servos

Whats been changed/added:

Hexapod Body:
Removed old mounting holes and created new holes to mount the Pi.
Cut holes for the servo arms to sit in (The servo arms are usually made out of a flexible plastic so mounting on top allows the arms to twist making the whole thing less stable).
Widened the mounting section for the head and gave it two holes for stability.

Hexapod Legs:
Cut holes for the servo arms on the leg mid-section (again to make it more sturdy and make the leg narrower).

Hexapod Other:
Added spacers for the Pi to sit on (As the pi has the bottom of the header pins sticking out the bottom on one side and to allow the WIFI dongle to sit straight). Glue these on the body before mounting the Pi.
Added mount for an Adafruit 16 channel servo module (this also serves as a cable tidy)

Camera Mount:
Modified bottom plate to attach instead of hexapod head.
Modified bottom plate cover to allow for new screw placement on bottom plate.

The only thing left is the power supply, You'll have to modify the tail section for your chosen battery setup.
I will be adding the code once I've had time to do it :)

title: Crosshair and Pepperbox Antenna framework for 2.4 and 5.8 builds

description.text:
IB Crazy designed the circularly polarized crosshair antenna, and also the pepperbox antenna.

He told us how to make them on this blog,

http://fpvlab.com/forums/showthread.php?3626-Crosshair-10-dbic-Circularly-polarized-antenna-tutorial!

These 3D models make things a lot easier like, getting your Balun height correct (1/4 inch copper tube is what these models are designed on), positioning and getting height for your elements correct.

I will post pictures of the builds with these models as soon as I have done one.

Please note, IT DOES NOT MATTER WHAT THICKNESS YOUR REFLECTOR IS, the standoff squares fit to the front of the reflector and so the material you use will not matter.

Please provide feedback if you have any! (i'm not an antenna guru or anything)

print_settings.Notes:: Note that for sake of completion I have included the hinged gate rod which runs through the gate posts. I find it better to use something a bit stronger like wire, plastic dowel or thin wooden dowel - I used a piece of wire coat hanger. The gates were also attached to the rotating centre gatepost pieces using thin gauge wire - wargame modellers will be familiar with this pinning technique. The sites for these are marked on the gates and posts with narrow holes

description.text:
This fortified gateway is effectively Part Two of the already uploaded modular Saxon Burh Walls which had an open gateway (handy if you're a marauding viking). As previously the model represents a gateway for a Saxon fortified town/burh in the age of Alfred the Great of Wessex at the time of the viking invasions. It is scaled to be suitable for use with 28mm wargaming or model figures

Also included in this package is a half-wall that I forgot to put in the original package because I'm senile. You will need the half wall/walls if you are making a whole burh and are using the gateway (always a good idea for entering/exiting) or some of the curved wall sections

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Fine

Notes:

See the exploded diagram for gatepost/hinge assembly.

Note that for sake of completion I have included the hinged gate rod which runs through the gate posts. I find it better to use something a bit stronger like wire, plastic dowel or thin wooden dowel - I used a piece of wire coat hanger. The gates were also attached to the rotating centre gatepost pieces using thin gauge wire - wargame modellers will be familiar with this pinning technique. The sites for these are marked on the gates and posts with narrow holes

Painting

As with the other models, mine were undercoated in gesso, painted with acrylics, and varnished in matt

Feet for the Ultimaker 2 series to protect the printer's hard corners and the table underneath. I printed mine in Ninjaflex with 50 % intill and it seems (further testing required) to have decreased ringing a bit as well. Win-win. =)

author: Kumardebu

title: Cat or dog bowl with anti-bugs moat

description.text:
This bowl can be used for cats or dogs and has a moat around it so that you can pour water on the moat to prevent ants and other bugs from getting to your pet's food.  
I would advise to use a very low infill (say, 5% - zero will not work) and then filling it with pebbles as you print, for it to have some weight; this might be needed because pets have that tendency to keep pushing things around. I myself modelled this object after a metal bowl I have which is quite heavy for this exact reason.  
I made this in inkscape, imported into openscad, then rotate_extruded it to get its shape.  
WARNING: Please take notice that this is only an experiment. These bowls are very easy and cheap to find here in Campinas, Brazil, and they come as metal bowls with special coating. However, neither printed PLA nor ABS is food-safe due to the small cervices that serve as an habitat for potentially harmful bacteria. The 'moat' on my bowl is where you pour water or any other liquid, and bacteria will flourish in the small droplets of water. If you insist on using it for your cats, I would suggest giving it an acetone vapor bath, since is smooths the surfaces and seem to close the small crevices (I am not sure if it does).

• Use a low infill and drop some pebbles into it while printing to give it some weight. This will preventing your pet from dragging it around.
  • If you do this, use thick wall settings, specially on the bottom. You do not want the pebbles to ruin your bowl by breaking its walls. In slic3r, you can go to print settings ÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂ-> layers and perimeters ->ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ vertical shells ÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂ-> layers and perimeters: (at least 5); and horizontal shells ->ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ (at least 6 on the bottom one)
  • The bowl has a ~15cm diameter. You might want to scale it up or down depending on your needs.

comments.text: Wonderful idea!  From experience and as the say in the movies, I think "You're going to need a bigger moat".  Ants will sometimes make a body bridge and/or use falling food bits to cross moats.  Again, I think this is a great idea!  You could also use this as the base for a normal metal dish to separate the ABS/PLA from the pet food.
comments.author: cfg

comments.text: Thanks! As far from the tests I made, it seems the moat is effective against the ants - I have lots of them in my front yard and they usually swarm into the cat food in plastic bowls; with the moat, they were unable to do it. Maybe for other ant species only a larger moat would be effective, I'll work on a variation for that.

title: MINI R56 - LG G3 holder in CD driver

description.text:
Few weeks ago I bought MINI Cooper R56, year 2007, but I had one issue: Where can I place my smartphone LG G3? I don't like windshield holder, it covers my view, it still falls from window because of big weight of smartphone.

I found some holders for MINI, but nothing fits for my requirements. So I designed my own.
This holder fits to the CD drive very well, smartphone is turned directly to my face (20 degrees to the left, 10 degrees up), so smartphone display look nicely to me :)

TODO:

Notes:

My printer is not the best (as you can see on images), but after all it fits very good.

Glue it together

After print CD Drive part and smartphone holder part, you need glue it together. I really recommend to use Super glue (you know this small 3 grams tubes?), press two parts together with enough force, wait for dry the glue. Done :)

Paint it

As I print with white ABS only, I wanted to change color. I found some silver spray from my old car, so I spray holder with 2 layers of paint and 3 layers of transparent lack.

Add soft pads

Holder for LG G3 has little spaces for soft pads which holds smartphone much better and it protects holder and smartphone from getting scratches.

I glued it with Super glue again. Material of this soft pads is some kind of polystyrene, 2mm thick(see last image). But I think it's doesn't really matter what you use, just try something nice :) I added 2 pads on each side and 2 longer pad on back side of holder. All you can see on images, it's gray-white-transparent stuff on holder.
